awd_titl_txt: RUI: Behavior of Trivalents in Metaphase I and Anaphase I
awd_abstract_narration:
Every time a cell divides, it must distribute the correct number of chromosomes to its daughter cells.  Chromosomes must be positioned correctly to ensure correct chromosome distribution during cell division.  Failure to correctly position chromosomes in cell division leads to aneuploidy (extra or missing chromosomes) and can be catastrophic for the cell and, ultimately, the organism. Chromosomes must attach to the spindle, typically with one attachment site facing each spindle pole.  This bipolar attachment guarantees that partner chromosomes will separate from one another in anaphase.  In metaphase, after forming a bipolar attachment, chromosomes of nearly all organisms align in the center of the spindle forming the metaphase plate.   The alignment of chromosomes in the center of the spindle in metaphase may be simply a consequence of the "tug of war" that the chromosome is experiencing as a result of a bipolar attachment, with both sides of the chromosome under equal tension.  Alternatively, the positioning of chromosomes at the center of the spindle could be essential for guaranteeing correct distribution in anaphase.   The fact that chromosomes align at the center of the spindle in nearly all cell types (the behavior is nearly universal), and that mutants that fail to align chromosomes produce aneuploid cells, suggests that that metaphase alignment at the center of the spindle is important for directing appropriate chromosome separation and movement in anaphase.  The aim of this project is to learn more about how chromosomes align at the center of the spindle, and how the placement and the timing of this alignment can impact distribution of chromosomes during anaphase.  The Broader Impact activities will address the problem that there are very few tools available to biology instructors for teaching cell division.  A series of narrated videos of different types of cell division will be created for use in the classroom, thus beginning a collection of materials for future projects. These videos will be distributed nationally to any instructor who desire to use them in their courses. 

In meiosis I, most chromosomes connect with one homologous or partially homologous partner to form a bivalent.  Bivalents align on the metaphase plate and then homologues initiate segregation at anaphase I onset.  However, in males from some taxa (e.g., praying mantids and the cellar spider Pholcus phalangioides), the X1, X2, and Y chromosomes form a trivalent during meiosis I.  The X1, X2, and Y chromosomes each have a single kinetochore, with X1 and X2 associating with one pole in metaphase I, while the Y chromosome associates with the other pole. Though the trivalent has two kinetochores facing one pole and one facing the other, it aligns with all autosomes on the metaphase I plate. In addition, metaphase I appears to be so important that anaphase I is delayed for the trivalent, with the autosomes separating approximately 20 minutes before the X1, X2, and Y chromosomes. This project aims to determine how forces are balanced to align the trivalent on the metaphase plate, and then how the chromosomes that make up the trivalent segregate correctly into daughter cells, using electron microscopy, laser microsurgery, immunofluorescence staining, and small molecule inhibitors.

por.por_cntn:
Every time a cell divides, it must correctly distribute chromosomes to daughter cells.  Failure to give each daughter cell the correct number of chromosomes can be catastrophic to the cell, or to the whole organism.  Correct distribution of chromosomes requires that each chromosome attach to the spindle so that it will then separate its partner chromosomes into daughter cells.  In general chromosomes will form a bipolar attachment, with one attachment site facing each spindle pole.  This bipolar attachment can be equated to an evenly-matched tug of war that leads to chromosomes aligning in the center of the spindle in metaphase.  Following alignment, the chromosomes then separate partners into daughter cells.  Both alignment and subsequent timely separation in anaphase appear to be important for maintaining cells with the right chromosome number.  We took a novel approach to studying chromosome alignment and timely separation by looking at naturally-occurring trivalent chromosomes in the spermatocytes of praying mantids and cellar spiders.  These trivalents are composed of an X1 chromosome, an X2 chromosome, and a Y chromosome (See attached images) and reveal interesting information about the importance of chromosome alignment and timely segregation. 

Unlike all other chromosomes that are composed of two equivalent partners and feel equal forces from both sides of the spindle, the trivalent has its Y chromosome facing one spindle pole, while the X1 and X2 face the opposite.  One might think that the side of the trivalent that has the X1 and X2 chromosomes might be closer to its associated spindle pole (as a 2 vs 1 tug of war might show the side with two people overpowering the side with one person).  During the granting period, we showed that four systems with naturally-occurring trivalents align those trivalents on the center of the spindle with every other chromosome.  Our work confirms previous work in fixed specimens and shows for the first time that that alignment is maintained in living cells (see attached images).  We also show that the X1 and X2 chromosomes form weaker attachments to the spindle than the Y chromosome does, and than all of the other chromosomes, and continue to study how that alignment is regulated.

We also used the trivalent system to study timely separation of chromosomes in anaphase.  Separation of chromosomes usually happens so that all chromosomes separate at the same time.  However, in one of our systems that has a trivalent (the cellar spider) the trivalent lags behind all other chromosomes (see attached images).  Lagging chromosomes often lead to problems with normal functioning of daughter cells, so we can gain a lot of benefit from having a model that can explain some of the causes of lagging.  Lagging potentially can either result from attaching incorrectly to the spindle or from a failure to separate partner chromosomes.  During the grant period, we learned that the cellar spider trivalent is an example where the chromosome attaches correctly, and the spindle attachment sites move to spindle poles in anaphase, but they cannot separate the X1 and X2 from the Y chromosome.  This is different from most other systems with a lag, where attachment to the spindle explains the failure to separate.

For Broader Impacts we have created and posted several videos either illustrating cell division or showing the process in living cells to be used as teaching tools.  We continue to seek more examples and hope to generate a rich source of illustrations and living cell material to share with students everywhere.
